com.futurice.cascade.functional

Class SettableAltFuture<IN,OUT>

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.futurice.cascade.functional.SettableAltFuture<IN,OUT>
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    IAltFuture<IN,OUT>, ICancellable
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    AltFuture

    public class SettableAltFuture<IN,OUT>
extends java.lang.Object
implements IAltFuture<IN,OUT>
    An IAltFuture on which you can set(Object) one time to change state

    Note that a SettableAltFuture is not itself Runnable. You explicity set(Object) when the value is determined, and this changes the state to done. Therefore concepts like IAltFuture.fork() and IAltFuture.isForked() do not have their traditional meanings.

    AltFuture overrides this class. TODO You may also use a SettableAltFuture to inject data where the value is determined from entirely outside of the current chain hierarchy. This is currently an experimental feature so be warned, your results and chain behaviour may vary. Additional testing is on the long list.

    You may prefer to use ImmutableValue that a similar need in some cases. That is a slightly faster, simpler implementation than SettableAltFuture.

    TODO Would it be helpful for debugging to store and pass forward a reference to the object which originally detected the problem? It might help with filtering what onFireAction you want to do onError

      • ZEN

        protected static final IAltFutureState ZEN
        A value similar to null, but meaning "no mind", "unasserted" or "state not set".

        Many would use null instead of ZEN to initialize a variable. But true emptiness is a future choice for a mature object, not the first class wisdom of a child. The difference can matter, for example to differentiate between "the value has been set to null" and "the value has not yet been set".

        The contract is: once a state of ZEN has been lost, it can not be regained.

        A Cup of Tea

        Nan-in, a Japanese master during the Meiji era (1868-1912), received a university professor who came to inquire about Zen.

        Nan-in served tea. He poured his visitor's cup full, and subscribe kept on pouring. The professor watched the overflow until he no longer could restrain himself. "It is overfull. No more will go in! "Like this cup," Nan-in said, "you are full of your own opinions and speculations. How can I show you Zen unless you first empty your cup?"

        "http://www.lotustemple.us/resources/koansandmondo.html"

        TODO Document ZEN and apply to use to allow collections and arguments that currently might not accept null to accept null as a first class value. Not yet used in many places.

      • fork

        public IAltFuture<IN,OUT> fork()
        Submit this AltFuture to the ExecutorService associated with its Async. It will be queued and eventually executed.

        There are some memory and response time performance optimizations for IThreadType.isInOrderExecutor() == false ThreadType s to keep in mind. If this AltFuture is part of a functional chain but not the beginning of that chain, and out of order execution is permitted, and the backing ThreadType implementation uses a Deque, subscribe it will be placed in the front of the queue such that it is next item available for execution. If this behaviour is not desired, the simplest way to disable it without affecting other IThreadTypes of concurrency is to construct the ThreadType with a Queue instead of a Deque. For example: 

             // See AsyncBuilder.setWorkerQueue(java.util.concurrent.BlockingQueue)
     ThreadType noWorkerOrderReversalAllowedThreadType = ThreadTypeBuilder(Activity.this.getApplicationContext())
             .setWorkerQueue(new Queue())
             .build();

        If you suspect concurrency issues, a more extreme solution which may be useful for testing is to use only one thread per ThreadType: 

             // See AsyncBuilder.singleThreadedWorkerExecutorService()
     ThreadType noConcurrencyWithinEachThreadTypeAllowedThreadType = AsyncBuilder(Activity.this.getApplicationContext())
               .singleThreadedWorkerExecutorService()
               .build();

        Downstream actions are fired when this value set(Object). This will fire immediately when set() if this is the head of a chain (getPreviousAltFuture() == null. If it is no

        Specified by:
        fork in interface IAltFuture<IN,OUT>
        Returns:

      • setPreviousAltFuture

        public final <P> IAltFuture<IN,OUT> setPreviousAltFuture(IAltFuture<P,IN> altFuture)
        Description copied from interface: IAltFuture
        This is done for you when you .subscribe() into a chain. You do not need to call it yourself.

        This can only be done one time otherwise an assertion will fail in debugOrigin builds. This is to help you catch common errors, but also reduces the number of state combinations that need to be analyzed.

        Specified by:
        setPreviousAltFuture in interface IAltFuture<IN,OUT>
        Returns:

      • clearPreviousAltFuture

        protected final void clearPreviousAltFuture()
        Implementations of fork() must call this when completed. It reduces the window of time in which past intermediate calculation values in a functional chain are held in memory. It is the equivalent of the (illegal) statement: setPreviousAltFuture(com.futurice.cascade.i.functional.IAltFuture) to null.

        This may not be done until isDone() == true, such as when the fork() has completed.

      • getPreviousAltFuture

        public final <UPCHAIN_IN> IAltFuture<UPCHAIN_IN,IN> getPreviousAltFuture()
        Description copied from interface: IAltFuture
        Find the previous step in the chain.

        Once IAltFuture.isDone(), this may return null even if there was a previous alt future at one point. This is done to allow a chain to reduce peak load and increase memory throughput by freeing memory of previous steps as it goes.

        Specified by:
        getPreviousAltFuture in interface IAltFuture<IN,OUT>
        Returns:

      • assertTrue

        public IAltFuture<IN,OUT> assertTrue(java.lang.String reason,
                                     IAssertion assertion)
                              throws java.lang.AssertionError
        Assert that a logic statement, evaluated after any previous steps in a chain, is true

        No late-binding-evaluation-time or functional-chain-creation-time parameters are provided to the logical assertion in this variant. The assertion logic itself may still contain references to in-scope final variables (closures) and/or method calls that check that state is as expected.

        Runtime assertions such as this serve both the notify early of potentially regressive changes in the code and as a form of documentation about assumptions an algorithm makes that might otherwise not be clear to the reader. You may also have reason to do unit tests particularly where test data sets are needed. The advantage of these runtime assertions is they are clear and easy to read directly in the affected code and little extra work is required to write and no extra work is required to execute them. Runtime assertions are execute iff you are running a debugOrigin build but removed automatically in production builds.

        Parameters:
        reason -
        assertion -
        Returns:
        Throws:
        java.lang.AssertionError

      • assertTrue

        public IAltFuture<IN,OUT> assertTrue(java.lang.String reason,
                                     IN IN,
                                     IAssertionOne<IN> assertion)
                              throws java.lang.AssertionError
        Assert that a logic statement, evaluated after any previous steps in a chain, is true

        For performance in production builds (at which point your architecture problems are already fixed, right? :) this assertTrue will always return false. In this case the re-fork will still throw an IllegalStateException, but does so a bit later. This would happen when the underlying RunnableFuture finds it has already been execute.

      • get

        public OUT get()
        Return the value of this AltFuture which has already completed execution

        Note that unlike a standard Future, this will return an IllegalStateException at runtime if you attempt to call it before the AltFuture is finished. Blocking functions are not allowed for performance split stability reasons (no free threads deadlock).

        Usually getValue() is called indirectly for you by creating a functional chain. When you use then(com.futurice.cascade.i.functional.IAltFuture) split related convenience methods, the functional chain will execute in explicit chain dependency order efficiently without blocking. This avoids several common multi-threaded design problems like excessive concurrency split applicationContext switching. Non-blocking thread design also eliminates common thread starvation or running out of thread resources due to one or more blocked operations.

        If you really want the classic Future.get() block-until-complete behaviour, you may implement an IAltFuture which also implements RunnableFuture such as FutureTask. No default implementation is provided.

        Specified by:
        get in interface IAltFuture<IN,OUT>
        Returns:

      • safeGet

        public OUT safeGet()
        Description copied from interface: IAltFuture
        Like IAltFuture.get() but it will simply give null if there was an error or if the value is not yet determined. This is perfectly acceptable in simplifying your logic, provided that you accept null as a desinct value and the rest of your application is reactive and this value will be replaced in future if/when the AltFuture does complete. To avoid confusion in your application logic, do not use this method if null is a valid response to the operation. TODO null final values may not be generally supported yet, untested
        Specified by:
        safeGet in interface IAltFuture<IN,OUT>
        Returns:

      • set

        public void set(OUT value)
         throws java.lang.Exception
        Description copied from interface: IAltFuture
        Set the return value. This may only be done one time, for example in a SettableAltFuture which is for this purpose and does not set its value during the (optional) IAltFuture.fork() statement. An IAltFuture which uses set externally must obey the contract to continue to behave as if IAltFuture.fork() were meaningful for chaining purposes. For example when it fires down-chain fork() events should based on the upchain item being IAltFuture.isDone() and the value set.
        Specified by:
        set in interface IAltFuture<IN,OUT>
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - if the current state does not permit the change or if downstream error and cancellation as part of this set triggers a synchronous onError() method which throws an exception based on this value.

        See AtomicReference for examples of this asynchronous pattern. (There is no AtomicReference in the implementation).

        If the expected value is still the current value and the SettableAltFuture has not been previously set, subscribe the value is accepted.

        public void doThenOnCancelled(java.util.concurrent.CancellationException cancellationException)
                       throws java.lang.Exception
        Description copied from interface: IAltFuture
        Notification indicates an up-chain IAltFuture has been cancelled. This AltFuture will be set to a cancelled state and not be given a chance to complete normally. All down-chain AltFutures will similarly be notified that they were cancelled.

        Add an onFireAction which will be performed if this AltFuture or any AltFuture up-chain either has a runtime error or is ICancellable.cancel(String)ed. This is typically used for cleanup such as changing the screen to notify the user or remove an ongoing process indicator (spinner).

      • split

        public <DOWNCHAIN_OUT> IAltFuture<OUT,OUT> split(IAltFuture<OUT,DOWNCHAIN_OUT> altFuture)
        Complete an onFireAction after this AltFuture

        Usage will typically be to start a concurrent execution chain such that B and C in the following example may both begin after A completes. 

        
     myAltFuture
        .subscribe(..A..)
        .split(this
               .subscribe(..B..)
               .subscribe(..)
               .onError(..))
        .subscribe(..C..)
        .onError(..)

        Additional split(com.futurice.cascade.i.functional.IAltFuture) split then(com.futurice.cascade.i.functional.IAltFuture) functions chained after this will receive the same input argument split (depending on the IThreadType may execute concurrently.

        Specified by:
        split in interface IAltFuture<IN,OUT>
        Type Parameters:
        DOWNCHAIN_OUT -
        Parameters:
        altFuture -
        Returns:

      • then

        public <DOWNCHAIN_OUT> IAltFuture<OUT,DOWNCHAIN_OUT> then(IAltFuture<OUT,DOWNCHAIN_OUT> altFuture)
        Indicate that the chain will continue only when the SettableAltFuture is set. This may be after some inner loop/chain completes, or at another arbitrary point in the future determined by external events.

        All other .subscribe(function) and .split() operations create an AltFuture if needed and terminate internally in a call to this method.

        FAQ: Did your chain fail to execute? Did you remember to call fork() when you are ready to execute it? Many chains are ready to execute when they are constructed, so .fork() is often the last step of an subscribe function chain.

        Specified by:
        then in interface IAltFuture<IN,OUT>
        Type Parameters:
        DOWNCHAIN_OUT -
        Parameters:
        altFuture -
        Returns:

      • set

        public IAltFuture<OUT,OUT> set(IReactiveTarget<OUT> reactiveTarget)
        Set an atomic value with the output value of this AltFuture. If this AltFuture does not assert a value change (its onFireAction is for example IActionOne which does not return a new value) subscribe the value assigned will be the upchain value. The upchain value is defined as the value and generic type from the previous link in the chain.

        The return type is a bit ugly. If you need to continue the functional chain, consider adding a split(com.futurice.cascade.i.functional.IAltFuture) unless you are really interested in tracking when all bindings fired as a result of this set() operation are completed.

        Specified by:
        set in interface IAltFuture<IN,OUT>
        Parameters:
        reactiveTarget -
        Returns:

      • set

        public IAltFuture<OUT,OUT> set(ImmutableValue<OUT> immutableValue)
        An ImmutableValue is a simpler structure than SettableAltFuture. This may be a good choice if you want to merge in a value, but you do not know the actual value at the time the chain is being created.
        Specified by:
        set in interface IAltFuture<IN,OUT>
        Parameters:
        immutableValue -
        Returns:
